content.html_value:
The understanding of a text goes beyond simply reading the words it contains. Concepts, such as the dimensions of the "world", change over time. Words are added to or removed from a language, and even the alphabet undergoes transformations.

Could the study of mathematics help in understanding literature and text comprehension? This is precisely what we aim to explore in this section.

Like any knowledge, Literature is also directly connected to the language of mathematics. For this reason, we begin this section with Chapter 6 of the First Steps, which is dedicated to the study of mathematics in connection with other sciences. Thus, we recommend reading the first five chapters of that part before continuing (History Tracers Editors, First Steps).

Although in school we are introduced to subjects called Science or Literature before entering university, teaching often limits itself to presenting only the initial stages of this field. These stages could be referred to as proto-Literature or pre-Literature, as proposed by Dr. Francisco González A. Redondo (González Redondo, Francisco A., ; González Redondo, Francisco A., ; History Tracers Team, The knowledge).

In the texts of this section, we present the concepts of pre-Literature and proto-Literature, gradually connecting them to Literature through mathematics.

value.name: Literature and science
value.desc: it is not uncommon to hear that a text represents the truth, but what is truly true about that?

value.name: Limits and contexts
value.desc: a common point between science and writing is the fact that people do not always understand their limits. But how can we identify them?

content.html_value: Chapter 2: To be or not to be...

value.name: On Equality
value.desc: In this text, we begin exploring the concept of comparison and the methods for grouping identical objects.

value.name: Equality Levels
value.desc: Some concepts, like the definition of a planet, change over time. Sometimes, objects with slightly different sizes can be considered equal. How can we use numbers to quantify equality?

value.name: Are we truly equal?
value.desc: In this text, we explore the acceptable limits of inequality and emphasize that within our species, there are no races.

value.name: Bigger or Smaller
value.desc: Concluding the comparisons, we analyze the relationship between objects by classifying them as bigger or smaller.

value.name: Reading and Multiplying
value.desc: Multiplication helps us navigate a text we are reading.

value.name: Shared Origin
value.desc: After observing different ways of grouping and counting quantities, we moved on to studying the sharing of those quantities.

value.name: Simplicity vs. Complexity
value.desc: Despite more than 13.8 billion years of evolution of the universe, we often still wish to be like it was in its beginnings. Why?

value.name: Two sides
value.desc: good and evil, left and right, matter and energy, up and down. Is this duality enough?

value.name: Expanding...
value.desc: Continuing from the previous text, we see that dividing into just two sides ends up doing omissions

value.name: Always present
value.desc: many times we are so focused on ourselves or on opposites that we do not notice what is always present.

value.name: Evolution of Knowledge (Atom)
value.desc: In this text, we study how our idea of the atom has evolved over time.

value.name: The Writing System
value.desc: More than just a tool for daily use, the writing system is a milestone that allows us to divide human history into prehistory and recorded events.

value.name: Walking Among the letters
value.desc: In this text, we explore the relationships between integers and texts.

value.name: Playing with Consonants and Vowels
value.desc: An interactive game to understand how syllables are created.

value.name: Building Words with Syllables
value.desc: In this text, we will explore how to construct words using syllables.

value.name: The word
value.desc: when we combine syllables, we form a word, but what exactly is a word?

value.name: Grouping texts
value.desc: A text is more than just a sequence of words. In this study, we begin to examine ancient texts in detail, aiming to understand the elements that compose them.

value.name: Fractionating Texts
value.desc: In this text, we delve deeper into the concept of groups and introduce fractions as an additional tool for understanding texts.

value.name: Grouping Fractions
value.desc: After identifying the groups that make up a text, this section explains how to work with them.

value.name: Texts like vectors
value.desc: In this content, we will explore how vectors can help us better understand the information and structures present in texts.

value.name: Texts with Sciences (Part I)
value.desc: In the initial texts, we analyzed the relationship between texts and various scientific disciplines, though we have not yet achieved a complete textual interpretation. In this text, we begin exploring ancient Mesopotamian texts with the support of scientific research.

value.name: Texts with Sciences (Part II)
value.desc: After exploring some figures of speech present in ancient texts, a question arises: what was the context of the Flood?

value.name: Texts with Sciences (Part III)
value.desc: With everything we have learned, what conclusions can we draw from ancient texts that discuss deluges?

value.name: Texts with Sciences (Conclusion)
value.desc: After understanding the water cycle, it is time to investigate catastrophic events linked to this essential resource.
